Entry.1:
(Paris. cont.)

New Year's Day -

Army & Navy Leave Club

Windsor Hotel

With my friend I visit Bois-de-Boulonge, a reserve of 2.000 odd acres once used for hunting but now an immense park greatly frequented in summer. It has artificial lakes & cascades and is most popular with horse riding parties.

Return to town and thence to Wagram.

A cold & rainy night.
Entry.2: Shopping - Purchase of Paris views & books which I send Home. Meet Miss Rout, a New Zealand Lady who is "Bill jini's greatest friend while in Paris. Once again I visit Madame Monsieur & once again I recite Shakespeare - Afternoon chocolate - Entertainment in Paris and the Nationalisation of Opera & Drama - Georgette - Au Revour.
Entry.3:
My last days leave in Paris. Being any

thing but financial I am well content to re-visit the now familiar resorts - Garden of the Tiuleries- The Louvre (see Guide) Place de la Concorde - Champs Elysees - Port Alexandre III - Rue de Rivoli - Place de l'Opera (central spot in Paris) Boulevard des Italeens - Rue de la Paris (world famous for its Jewellers Shops) - Place de la Republique - Comedie Francais - Palais Royale & Place Vendome which contains Napoleon's Column - Paris - Its traffic

its shops, cafes, hotels, restaurants. trams, trains lighting - & Its people - Early to bed, after partaking of supper with Madame.

Jan
Entry.4:
Rise at 6 a.m. - and take train from Gare du Nord. A slow and a thoughtful journey. Arrive Aulnoye at 8 p.m - and spend night on the floor of a cafe - Such is the Army. It is always a case of going to or coming from the sublime to

the ridiculous.

Jan
Entry.5: Walk to ov 11 k.m to Avesnes to rejoin "the Coves", most of whom have arrived back before me. Naturally things are rather unsettled, and news regarding the future refuses to be made known to us.
Entry.6: Cleaning up day. A number of cards & photographs posted Home - Avesnes quite as uninteresting as ever.
Entry.7:
Paris Diary

re-written - also letters and another start made in my study of French.
Entry.8: Friends in Avesnes. French. Letters & cards. Cold but invigorating weather.
Entry.9: A day of correspondence & studying - Before we can again make a start several of our members have yet to return from London.
Entry.10: Letter writing and studying. In the afternoon the Camp Commandant arrives and after filling in our Demobilisation Papers we are told that for certain reasons "The Anzac Coves" are broken up & no longer exist as a Concert Party. We are then given a choice as to our next individual move - Application for "Corner of Blighty" - The spell is at last broken.
Entry.11: Second anniversary of my joining the "Coves" - Two years & what they meant. We are all light-hearted to-day - Letters - Emerson's Essays.
Entry.12:
Return of Harry from H.Qs with mail - Many letters & parcels. These 
of
 are days of great excitement for our Party. Hughie Gannon. Jack Davey. Bob Roberts. Tom Sutherby. Cyril Jessop & others begin first stage of journey to

Australia - I just miss.
Entry.13:
My 22nd Birthday - Our Party breaks up, some returning to their Units - others to 3rd Div. Artillery Concert Party while Harry, Frank, Les, Rupert & self leave for Aust. R.E. Workshops - where we are to reinforce a small entertaining troupe. Daily, good news is being received in regard to Australian & English Frulough.

Our new residence.
Entry.14:
A day of letter

writing and parcel packing - Over 12 letters posted in the afternoon.
Entry.15:
Third anniversary of leaving Australia. Now entitled to four blue stripes. Preparations for "R.E." shows.

Letter writing and the study of French.
Entry.16:
A motor lorry trip from Jeumont to Home. The former is in France & the latter in Belgium. A very cold ride. Arrve at Corps H.Qs and meet many

old friends. I am commissioned to collect the remainder of the Anzac Cove's costumes, curtains etc.

Some disclosures concerning our late Manager.

An unprincipled being.

Return after bidding Cyril & others farewell (prior to their departure for Australia) to Jeumont.

More Australian mail.
Entry.17:
Rehearsals commence once again. parcels & letters posted Home & to 
Australia
 England.

Our O.C. Lt Thomas his popularity -

my present Unit - "Australian Corps Engineers Workshops" - New faces - Duties practically nil.
Entry.19: Liberal terms regarding "Demobilisation" - Expecting to leave France in April. Rupert's news regarding position at Drury Lane. The Peace spirit throughout France & Belgium. Soldiers entertain & are entertained by civilians.
Entry.20:
Read "The Critic" (Sheridans) and study Hugo's French.

Correspondence.

- A mock court case.

- An afternoon walk
s
 & some evening chocolate.
Entry.21:
Rehearsal.

News regarding personal leave to London.

A stroll through "Jeumont" - Indescribable masses of wreckage on the railway line. Seventeen trains loaded with engines, dynamos,

agricultural implements etc. etc. together with eight lines, crossings etc have been destroyed beyond repair by German "kultur".

The effect of explosions on the surrounding houses.
Entry.22:
Letters to & from Paris - Rehearsal with "The Remnants" -

Watching and awaiting for events of interest.
Entry.23:
Last rehearsal, and opening night of the Workshop Concert Party - A good house,

and a willing but inartistic lot of boys. The late "Anzac Coves" all acquit themselves excellently - Madame & Monsieur.
Entry.24:
There are now but few of the "1915" men left in France - "A hopeful outlook". The weather bitterly cold.

Second night of programme. Owing to scarcity of khaki in this region there is a decided drop in the takings.

After having previously played "Knight"

in the sketch entitled "A Tabloid". I am now playing the more important part of "Sherwood".

Frank Crossley the third member.
Entry.25:
A walk through, & beyond Jeumont.

Meet, - McKenna from Balmain (Pal of Roy Mc's).

Letters to Home & England - "Rhymes of a Red Cross Man" - third show.
Entry.26:
Anniversary Day - Sydney Harbour and its Regatta.

Bobby Roberts pays a visit. A dance in the Theatre. Attended by soldiers & civilians.
Entry.27:
Departure for England postponed till Wednesday owing to two extra shows being decided on. Packing up in anticipation.

A yarn with Stan Savage and some surprises regarding the past.
Entry.28: Writing. Reading & final show. Pack up
Entry.29:
Leave Jeumont at 9 a.m. with Rupert Brown for London.

First stage of journey in motor-lorry to Charleroi - where we spend afternoon in looking round town before entraining in the Evening.

Meet Sid Alder, Capt. Potts etc. Entrain in Calais bourd troop train at 10 p.m. and leave Charleroi at midnight.
Entry.30:
A cold, slow, miserable, sleepless and practically a

foodless journey.

We pass through Mons, Tournai, Lille,Armentieres, Bailleul. Steenvorde. Hazelbrouck and other well-known towns & villages the majority of which are completely devastated. "A cattle truck journey and what it is like!" The Calais line being blocked our train makes for Dunkerque.
Entry.31:
Arrive Dunkerque - Disentrain and at midday embark

for dear "Old Blighty" - Arrive at Dover at 3 p.m.

An incident concerning some Imperial Warrant Officers - as disgusting as it is contemptible. Arrive at Victoria and march to Horseferry Rd - after which I make for "Elm Bank" and arrive at my English Home more dead than alive. Mr & Mrs Scales are away but Alice attends to me like a true nurse and after medical attention I go to bed and sleep soundly.

February
Entry.32:
-

Awake with nothing more than a cold to my credit or should I say discredit. Late breakfast. Return of Mr Scales with whom I journey to Wanstead for purpose of meeting my Dear English Mother - Happy meeting - A long conversation and much laughter. Return to Highgate.
Entry.33:
Letters & Parcels prepared. Afternoon visit to Wanstead. Mrs Scales and her

work in connection with the Womens Auxiliary Missionary. The poems of Christina Ros
s
etti.
Entry.34:
.

Visit to Australian Comforts Fund & Horseferry Rd. Meet Mr Gannon but fail to find Ralph. Lunch at Canadian Beaver Hut The Strand. Go to matinee at the Palladium where Fred Barnes, Alfred Lester, HettyKing & Mardie Scott are on the "bill".

The great Tube strike in London

Disorganisation - Evening trip to Wimbledon and return to "Elm-Bank".
Entry.35:
.

Taking things easy as a convalescent would do. Letters written & parcels posted.

Matinee at the London Coleseum where I see and hear Russian Ballet (Daghlieff) . Mark Hambourg (Pianist) Vester Pilley etc. The London Tube strike and its effect on passenger traffic.

Snow storms and black mists. Again

visit Mrs Scales at Wanstead and meet the Misses Nutter. Back to Home.

5h Feb.

A morning spent in the Library of Mr Scales. Upwards of 3,500 volumes.

Aftenoon visit to Mr & Mrs Matthews at Blackheath. A cold journey, during a heavy fall of snow, on the top of a London Bus. A hearty welcome and a very pleasant evening. Stay overnight. The hospitality of

host, hostess and their daughter Miss Honoui.
Entry.36:
Return to town. Call on Mr Fitzsimmons who unfortunately is away from office.

Matinee at the New Theatre. A thrilling and capibally acted play. "The Chinese Puzzle"- Ethel Irving, Lilian Braithwaite - Leon McLeon. Athol Stewart. Meet Rupert.

In the evening I see Charles Hawkey & Gladys Cooper at the "Playhouse"

a farce with "C.H." the predominating feature.
Entry.37: Writing & Reading. Mr & Mrs Scales return from Wanstead. Dinner with Mr & Mrs Harold at "Westcott".
Entry.38: Morning, afternoon & evening at "Elm Bank". Such a way of spending the day holds a greater appeal and more charm than jostling along the busy London like so many aimlessly do.
Entry.39:
(Sunday)

Letters Home. London in Winter. An afternoon of exercise and amusement. Walk to Parliament in the Fields, which lies adjacent to Hampstead Heath - and there I witness
ing
 the delightful recreation of tobogganing for the first time.

Great sport. Many laughs! Return to Elm Bank and spend the evening reading aloud to Mr & Mrs Scales.
Entry.40:
Miss Doris Scales (Niece of Mr & Mrs) arrives from Cambridge to spend week at "Elm Bank".

Morning and afternoon in London. Booking for Theatres etc.

Visit residence of Miss Fitzsimmons but have no luck as she is not at home.

Reading & writing.
Entry.41:
Another walk to "Parliament in the Fields" which was the original meeting place of the .

. More tobogganing & skating. A spectator only.

Miss Doris Courtney & myself.

A dinner & evening at "Elm Bank". Many guests - musical items etc (9 items).
Entry.42: Letters. Matinee at the Savoy. A.E. Matthews & Kenee Kelly in "Nothing but the Truth". A farce which is both clever & mirth provoking. Much fun at Home.
Entry.43:
Shopping in town. The Times Book Club claims most attention. Collection of War Poems.

Afternoon & evening at "Elm Bank". Letters to Herb. Mail Home & Paris. Meet Mr & Mrs Bower. The delightful company of Miss Scales.
Entry.44:
Morning & afternoon in town; continue search for books.

Pay visit to National Art Gallery where I see many of the

Great Masters.

Velasquez, Veronese, Michel Angelo. Tintoretto. Titian. Leonardo de Vinci. Turner. Gainsborough. Reynolds. etc.

In the evening Mrs. & Miss Scales & self greatly enjoy my first Shakespeare play "The Twelfth Night"- a record breaking production by James Bernard Fagan at the "Court Theatre". A most artistic show admirably acted throughout (see souvenir of same) Mary Grey. Arthur Whitly & Herbert Watson( ?).
Entry.45:
Reading & Writing.

Matinee at the Strand which features Arthur Bourchier. Noel Coward. Alex Scott Gatty & Kyrle Bellew - A poor play with no decent situation or dialogue and certainly no 
oc-cup
 opportunities for good acting.

Return to Elm Bank and have very pleasant evening. Read "Nonsense Novels" & "De Omnibus".
Entry.46:
(Sunday)

Morning of writing and preparation

Afternoon with Miss Doris at Mr & Mrs Harold Scales' Home. Peggy & Phoebe, their pretty little children.

A heart to heart talk with my dear English Mother - "Elm Bank" and my great love for it!

A new Light!

Bed at midnight.
Entry.47:
Arise at 4.30 a.m. - the parting. Take 6.18 a.m. train from Victoria to Folkestone
s
where we embark at 9.30 a.m.

Arrive at Calais & march to Military Camp. Back to the Army again.

"Night and the stars are gleaming"! But not in France my dear. Under canvas we rest atnight and hear the gentle drip, drip of the 
dr
 rain drops, and wonder if the tram tickets in Sydney are still the same shape & colour as they used to be.
Entry.48:
Entrain for

Charleroi - a journey which knows no joys. Night on the train.
Entry.49:
Pass through Bailleul. Steenwench. Armentieres. Lille. Tournai & Charleroi. Walk with pack from Charleroi to Beaumont - a distance of 23 kilo-metres (15 miles).

Billet for night at Beaumont.
Entry.50:
Set out from Beaumont and arrive at Jeumont.

Hearty welcome.

- Make up for lost meals & sleep.

- Begin to read "World Builders All".
Entry.51: A long letter to "Elm Bank"- Diary for English furlough re-written.
Entry.52:
Many letters written. Complete reading of "World Builders All".

Preparation of New Repertoire.
Entry.53:
Sabbath - Future Plans & Hopes.

- Walk to Erguillines. Receive Australian & English Mail. Commence replying to same.

- New Testament (Second Reading).
Entry.54: Second reading of "Palgrave's Golden Treasury" - More letters written - New Repertoire -OXENHAM SERVICE "AUSTRALIAN POETS" - etc.
Entry.55:
Second reading of "World Builders All".

Letter writing - Rehearsal - Learn new numbers.
Entry.56:
"Palgrave's Golden Tre
aa
sury of Verse"-

Diary - "World Builders All"-

Completion of replies to letters.
Entry.57: Additions to repertoire - Bad weather. A show that has a good reception "Lichtenberg" & "Ma..Poo" - Golden Treasury of Verse.
Entry.58:
Sitting & waiting for a last trip across the Channel.

Peace Conference - M. Clemenceau. Pres. Wilson's return to U.S.A.

- New items prepared.

- Further unpleasant weather. Commence reading "Pilgrim's Progress" - The Faith grows - absence of melancholia.

March - 1919
Entry.59:
A morning walk - German destruction - "Pilgrim's Progress".

Receive letters from London & Birthday Parcel from Home - a huge cake and its "baptism of fire".

- A Cinema show that proves a failure.
Entry.60:
(Sunday)

Continue reading "Pilgrim's Progress". Learn poems from "Golden Treasury".

Write letters to Home & "Elm Bank".
Entry.61: March rains & winds - Present months sailings to Australia clear the air a little. Jeumont as uninteresting as ever. The "Daily Mail" affords a little diversion. More letters - and "Pilgrim's Progress concluded.
Entry.62:
The "Mardi-Gras" or "Shrove Tuesday" - Pre-war celebrations cancelled. Prepare new items. Write "final" letters to friends

"old & new" - Dinner at the house of Monsieur la Chasseur.
Entry.63:
Investigations reveal the fact that I am not on the "demobilisation list". Such is the organisation of the "R.E.W." Having given particulars for third time I now find myself in the next draft - this going to leave, when?

A morning walk and a French "dejeuner" .

Once again I break forth into a "writing"

mood and write three poems.
Entry.64:
Commence reading "Book of Snobs"" (Thackeray).

Heavy rainfall
s
 - Frank leaves for Blighty. For first time I become "Cashier" and Box Office Man.
Entry.65: Still busy with "repertoire". Letter to Madame Griffie. The waiting game begins to pale. Peace Conference and its successful issue
Entry.66:
New members join "Remnants" - Two new poems written - Box Office duties.

Long letter from Elm Bank.

- "Book of Snobs".
Entry.68: Box Office & Cashier Duties - "Book of Snobs".
Entry.69:
Letters written - New & original poems. Ralph Sawyer reports

from Horseferry Rd. for duty at Aust. C.R.E. Further news of R. Carlisle.
Entry.70:
Rain & wind - wind & rain - Scarcity of letters. "The growing Faith". The absence of melancholia.

Usual duties.
Entry.71:
Third anniversary of leaving Egypt for France on the "Minneapolis". A visit to the Ambulance - Old faces & old memories.

- An endeavour to return to 7th for purpose

of early demobilisation.

- Charleroi - Jeumont.
Entry.72:
Letters to and from Blighty. News of R. Browne & Mark.

Complete book of "Snobs" - New poem.

Shipping troubles interfere with embarkation.
Entry.73:
Still Cashiering!

- Oh! the monotony of sitting & waiting.

- Washing-day - Energy & Sunligh soap.
Entry.74:
Sabbath -

A long walk -





The New Testament.

A Universal Religion.

Its possibilities.

Letters to English & Australian Homes.

Application for return to the Ambulance.
Entry.75: Booking during the day. Letters written. Times are very dull, but I am not discontented.
Entry.76: Diary - A canal-side walk with "Digger" - The New Repertoire
Entry.77: Third anniversary of arrival in France - Box Office Duties. "The impending strikes" - Letters.
Entry.78:
Another anniversary. Two parcels posted to Home.

News "re" Unit & demobilisation. Last day at Corps Workshops. Preparations for the morrow.
Entry.79:
Reveille 7 a.m. - Leave Aust Corps Workshops at Jeumont

for 7th Fld Amb. at Charleroi. Pass through Beaumont & Charleroi and complete the journey at Mont sur Marchienne where I rejoin the Unit after an absence of two years.

Only a few old faces remain - "5th & 7th" Ambulances amalgamate. An argument with the Q.M.

Jack Davey. Stan Capper. Bob Weir. Ern Goddard etc. etc.

- Search for a billet - The result
Entry.80:
A "snowstorm" repeats itself. Memories of Morbecque in 1916 - English Leave and Australian drafts cancelled indefinitely. Miners troubles. Meet more old acquaintances.

- A "Re-union Evening" of 7th F.A. Musical Items. Dancing. Refreshments. Many civilians present. Before coming to Charleroi I heard a good deal concerning the kindness and hospit-

ality of the Belgian people. Now I am personally having experience of their many good qualities, for I am in occupation of the finest billet in & around Charleroi. But then all of our"Boys" say the same. Monsieur & Madame Hiernaux and little Maria. Their love for the Australians. My appreciation of these new made friends and my "new home" .
Entry.81:
(Sabbath)

Letters to London - On "picquet" duty - The Motor transport lines. A soiree given by 5/7th F. Amb. A better & brighter evening.

"The spirit of Belgium" - The house of Monsieur Hiernaux - "et la chambre de Jim.

Back in Blighty - or perhaps Australia!
Entry.82:
Piquet-duty ends - Prospects of an early move - our disapproval - "Choc.

alate au lait". My approval!

An afternoon spent with the pen.
Entry.83:
New Poem. No duties. "The good & bad in races - Unfounded stories of the Belgians. The news regarding a move from Marchienne to Marcinelli fills the "troops" with dismay - Monsieur Hernaux and the petition -

His father a professor of Engineering - Himself a commercial man & a gentleman -

Supper nightly.
Entry.84:
Fatigue duties - Another Poem - A parcel from Home.

The stir caused by Sydney and "Our Harbour"- Reading writing & walking.

An evening with my new friends - Monsieur as a linguist - French. German. Spanish. Italian. English. Dutch. Flemish. etc.
Entry.85:
Official news of departure to "England"& thence "Australia" - Hurrah!!!

Madame et Monsieur sont tres triste! Another poem written, entitled "Australia".

Talks with M. Hiernaux.

Letter and book from "M.D.E.M.". Writing & Ambulance Duties.
Entry.86:
5/7th Fld. Amb. Final Dinner. Verses written.

Others posted to Australia - Piquet duties - The Boarding of the Draft. Mont-sur-Marchienne - Its people "His House in Order" (Pinero)
Entry.87:
Parade.



Clothing particulars.

Heavy snowfall.

Medical examination.

Letters to Home.

An agreeable break in the weather.

"Thanks, Australia, for lending us the Sun for a couple of hours".

Quiet, enjoyable evening.
Entry.88:
(Sabbath) Dinner with Monsieur & Madame. Preparations for departure. In marching order we leave M. & M. after being "farewelled" by troops & civilians

Heavy fall of snow.

Arrive Marchienne-au-Pont - then to Charleroi. Necessary demobilisation cards 
returne
 obtained.

Returned to Mont-sur-Marchienne for the evening and night.
Entry.89:
Reveillez 5.30 a.m. Early breakfast. Tearful farewell. Leave Monsieur & Madame whose generosity & kindness will always bring pleasant memories of Belgium - Charleroi - Speech by General. Our quota "No 23" (1,000 strong Infantry & Details 2nd Div).

entrain at 10 a.m. & as the train draws out from Charleroi an Australian band plays "Auld Lang Syne" and "Home Sweet Home".

- Troops well provided for - Food & comforts.

- Pass through Mons & Arras. etc.

April - 1919
Entry.90:
Light hearts & good fellowship. Glorious weather which improves as we go South.

A long day in the train - Incident concerning a Chinamen - Arrive at Harfleur (Le Havre) at midnight. Sleep in the train.
Entry.91:
Disentrain at 6 a.m. March to A.G.B.D. Meet old friends - Norman Frettell. Billy Dick. Disappointment through not seeing Herb

Medical inspection of "23" quota. Bathing & disinfection. Return of equipment.

Letters written. Diary.

Make the acquaintance of Frank Johnson the "South St" Elocutionist & Blue Ribbon Winner, who is showing with "Wattle Birds". The Frank that 
was
 and 
is
!
Entry.92:
From one camp to another. A dancing lesson (?)

Several parades.

Perfect weather .

A very interesting talk "re " Repatriation of A.I.F. Members.
Entry.93:
Clothing issue - Rations - Parade at 12.30 and move out of camp in motor lorries - to the harbour of Le Havre.

Embark on the St David and set sail for Southampton at 5 p.m. Military band plays the "Marseillaise" and "Good-byee" as our vessel leaves the land. A last long view of France

on a Sunny day. It is when we love France best. The sun is now bathing with its warm flood of light the early Spring flowers that grow wild in the wheat & corn fields and the vines that 
grow on
 creep over rustic village cottages.

The little white crosses that adorn the graves of our brave comrades seem bigger, brighter & bolder when skies are so blue and sun so golden. To all & everything in France & Belgium, my parting blessing & my tears!



1919

Diary. O.A.S.

from
Entry.94:
to



June 16th

Read "The Pocket Thackeray", which consists of popular excerpts from the works of the novelists - Note book entries - The "Rio Negro" is now reported to be 350 miles behind our ship. A nasty cold causes discomfort. A "home remedy" is brought to light.

June 17th

Nearing the "Cape" - four days sail to Cape Town. Will we be allowed ashore?

"Quiet Talks about the Tempter". (S.D. Gordon.)

Deck sport semi-finals - "B" deck reduces "D" deck's lead. Bible Class. Discussion on the Master's indignation in regard to our present day social, political and religious life.

Study of a "Short History of Australia" (SCOTT)

June 18th

Letter writing - Reading - Life-boat drill. Finals of deck sports. "C" Deck, the winners with 39 points our own deck second with 37.

A stiffSouth West wind has now been blowing many days and is apparently impeding our progress - our average is growing lower each day.

Notes from "Thackeray Book" - Australian History provides interesting study.

June 19th

The usual morning parade and inspection - A talk about Cape Town (which we expect to make by Saturday).

The Sports Prize giving Concert on the Aft Deck - "Carry On!" and the "Gas Helmet" given for first time. A beautiful moonlight night, and midnight meditations on the deck. The humours of the day: A digger is discovered playing "patience" at two o'clock in the morning.

June 20th

Diary - Continuation of the long letter to "Elm Bank". "Australian History".

sewing and washing.

- Late this evening we enter Table Bay and cast anchor.

June 21st

Steam across Table Bay at dawn and witness a beautiful and inspiring sunrise - My final glimpse and impressions of Cape Town - Far above us and stretching away for miles is "Table Mountain" (3,500 ft. high) so called because its top is flat and resembled a huge table. Below this table -

like formation is Table Bay which takes its name from the mount. Table Mountain with its precipitous cliffs has its long level summit hidden by dense white clouds, which gives it the appearance of being cloth-laid, while out of the valley the morning mists rise along the sheer side of the mountain. Likea lion crouching in an attitude of watchfulness, another section of the hills (appropriately termed "Lions Head")

rises (like Table Mountain) far above the City of Cape Town, which nestles at their respective bases and along the shores of Table Bay, while in depth it stretches from the shore to the Kloof.

- Docking & berthing facilities which are very good are in an artificial harbour, the numerous piers and break
ways
(waters) forming a system of wharfs and mooring places which are connected with the Town by a railway service.

The "Rio Pardo" is moored alongside of the Australian Transport "Aeneas" (which sailed from England four days after our departure and reached the Cape two days sooner). Greetings & "sarcasms" are exchanged.

At 11 a.m. the personnel of our vessel is granted leave for the day.

Unfortunately I am one of the few who are detailed to remain on duty. Apart from occasionally viewing Table Mountain. Table

Bay, Lions Head and the red roofed houses of Cape Town, I see nothing of the City, and so pass a quiet and rather a slow day.

In the afternoon mail is despatched to London & Sydney. At midnight Roy & Alf return with great reports of Cape Town and its people. A midnight meal of cakes and pastry is much enjoyed.

June 22nd

(Sunday)

A wet day! Malteureusement!(?)

At 11 a.m. Roy & I leave the Rio Pardo and walk into Cape Town. After a stroll along the main thoroughfare (Adderley St) and a spell in the Anzac Lounge (an institution which is under Y.U.C.A. supervision) we spend an hour of observation.

- Cape Town and its inhabitants. The Black & White Races and their divisions. The colour distinction as applied to the Kaffins.

- The White & Native

Quarters. A quaint church and its simplicity of style and architecture. We take a Camp Bay Car from the City in response to an invitation of yesterday and are shortly in the home of Mr Higgo - an old Cape Town resident. This part of the District is called the Kloof which is the Boer or Dutch equivalent of our word "Cleft".

It is actually the dip or valley which was between Table Mountain

and Lion's Head. The Kloof is clothed with pines and poplars out of which the mist can be seen rising to join the clouds above Table Mountain - Vegetation very similar to what may be seen in parts of Australia is also growing in the bed and on
e
 the sides of the Kloof.

Mr & Mrs Higgo. Mr & Mrs de Villiers and the sons & daughters of the former. In the home of Mr Higgo - "Kloof

Cottage", we are made very welcome by newly-made friends and we sample throughout the day pure, free & unadulterated hospitality as dispensed by "South Africa". A long talk with Mr Higgo who has resided in Kloof for twenty-eight years, and who for many years has been a health inspector
s
 on incoming vessels etc reveals much of interest.

Such
 
A great deal information is gained about the

S. African War - Cape Town and the surrounding districts. The natives, and S. Africa in general.

A self-supporting country - its achievements during the recent war.

After an 
h
early 
mid-day 
meal, which is sucha welcome change after Ship's food, we take a walk 
a
over the hill and down the road - in the direction of "Camps Bay" . Later in the evening a different road is taken and we

approach
ing
 by mean of a zig zag course, "Table Mountain".

The scenery (so different from England or France) is big, bold and in no less a degree 
inviting
 inspiring. Far away like a miniature city lies Cape Town on the shores of Table Bay.

While doing both walks we pass and are overtaken by numerous men & women who are on their way to and coming from the mountains. In

fact mountaineering appears to be a most popular past-time in the Cape Town District.

After tea Alf joins our party and we have a final stroll, followed by a musical evening.

"Lichtenberg"- brings together the names of S. Africa & Australia. Much fun & laughter.

S. African sport. Yarns about the famous "Springboks" and the "googly bowlers".

Good night and goodbye to Mr Higgo and family. These good people are friends of only a few hours acquaintance but we are not likely to forget them.

Back to the "Rio Pardo".

During the day the "Aeneas" has left for Australia (bearing our mail) and the "Beltana" has arrived in Cape Town.

June 23rd

The day of our departure -

News of the uninterrupted success of the Australian A.I.F. Cricket Team.

Lancashire defeated by an innings and 157 runs.

Brookes & Patterson are successful in the Doubles Final at Kent.

On the 15th inst. there has been a great "air flight accomplishment". Capt. Alcock makes the flight in 16½ hours.

Peace Terms are revised and submitted to Germany - and an acceptance is expected this day.

At 10 a.m. we have

a short route march returning to the ship at 11 a.m.

At mid-day the "Rio Pardo" is towed into "Table Bay", and then we commence in earnest the last stage of our voyage to Australia. Table Mountain & Lion's Head seen for the last time as our vessel draws away from land are indelibly printed in my mind.

Farewell "S.A."!

June 24th

A heavy sea is fortunately with us - and our transport makes good progress.

Further study of Australian History.

Mess Orderly duties taken up for four days.

June 25th

Duties on Troop Deck - Night recreation.

A skipping rope and a little deck space provides good exercise. Study of

Australian History.

June 26th

Heavy seas compel us to close all port-holes and to make preparations for battening down the hatch. Clear nights enable us to search the myriad-starred heavens in search of our Southern Cross.

Reading - The game of "Rummy".

June 27th

Conclusion of mess orderly

duties. The very interesting "History of Australia" draws to a close during the day. Much information regarding Australia from the days of Tasman, Dampier and Cook down to the Age of "Federation" and finally the Great War is gained by the perusal of this book.

Getting into form.

Prospects of a Physical Class being formed.

Growing tired of the

hammock life.

June 28th

The study of new items - Heavy seas cause the boat to roll more than what personal comfort calls for. During the day we ship many waves and the boys fight shy of the low open decks.

Washing day, but soon 'twill be no more!

"Old clothes, new clothes, boughtor souvenired clothes,

We have washed them cleanand washed them dirty,too, at times,

"Toilet soap or sand-soap,oft times do without soap,

Washing is as popular asthese unprinted lines

In the evening the glad tidings are brought to us (as per "wireless" from Durban) that Germany has signed the "Peace Terms" and we are at last truly the Victors 
of

June 29th

Sunday -

Morning church service.

- A strong and telling Sermon by the Padre

Vivid illustrations.

Afternoon Bible Class - Battles of the Old Testament. Evening Hym & Lantern Service.

The reciting of "Not Understood".

Another long letter to "Elm Bank" is commenced.

Fruit suppers are a welcome diversion from army issue and ships' food.

June 30th

Reading & writing. The last day of the second last month. We

have now been on the water 33 days and are growing happy with the knowledge that we have done a good deal more than half the voyage.
Entry.95:
July 1st

The last month in the Army!

Tuesday evening class. A new book commenced: "Our Boys Beyond the Shadow" by noteworthy clerics of England proves good reading and is productive of much thought.

The second stages of "deck sports".

Officers triumph in tug of war.

July 2nd

News of the Aeneas, Beltana & Durham. These three vessels are ahead of us and are experiencing rough weather.

Conclude "Our Boys Beyond the Shadow" .

The growing popularity of our Wednesday evening hymn service is well marked on this day, when despite the bitter winds, rough seas and failing light a good number of the "boys" sit out the service on deck.

Study of new items.

July 3rd

We wake in the morning to find a rough and angry sea tossing our boat contemptuously, with its huge rollers. As the hours pass the waters become more tempestuous, and it is neither comfortable nor safe to move about.

Finding the troop-deck rather crowded and stuffy (with all portholes closed) I climb the steps in search of fresh air. A glance to windward warns

me of approaching danger, and by natural impulse I dart into the hatchway just as a mountain-like wave crashes on to the "Pardo" sweeping its fore-deck and smashing the wash-house and rafts almost beyond recognition. At the same time the water finds an entrance to our troop-deck giving the boys a bath which was quite uncalled for. The whole action takes but three or four seconds, the noise and effect being not unlike the climax

to that sound which:-

 "Growing louder, shriller, clearer,Proclaims the heavy shell as it draws nearer."

This huge wave merely proves to be the first of many which sweep our decks throughout the day.

Night approaches, but the anger of the sea does not abate. Strange though it may seem, it is the same vast stretch of water.

"That running by the Castle of Old Windsor, reflects mirror-like the trees that line the river's banks.

Thus truly may we say with Byron -

"Thou glorious mirror,where the Almighty's form

Glasses itself in tempests; in all time,

Calm or convulsed - in breeze,or gale, or storm,

Icing the pole or in the torrid clime

Dark-heaving - boundless, endless, and sublime.

July 4th

American Independence Day, and the anniversary of

an eventful wedding.

As a result of the storm which still continues, our boat has lost many miles on the previous day's sailing, and is still doing so.

Sports, games, debates etc are cancelled.

The Study of the "Grammar of Elocution" (Millard).

July 5th

Allocation of Army Pay. The heavy seas greatly subside. We are now in wireless commun-

ication with Australia.

In the evening (while doing a little physical exercise) I skip in a single attempt 2,200

July 6th

 Sunday

Sunday morning service - the latter end of which is carried out in the rain. Another very forceful sermon by our Padre. Continuation of second letter written while at sea to "Elm Bank".

Sunday afternoon Bible class & evening hymn service.

Anniversary (nineteenth, I think) of Eva's birthday.

July 7th

Conclude "Grammar of Elocution" (Millard) and commence "Principles and Practice of Elocution" (H. Innes).

In the afternoon some sporting events, and in the evening a very interesting Debate.

The subject is "Should the R.S.A. be a Political body or not?"

"C" Company (with the negative side of the question),

defeat the Officers (affirmative).

Messages (per wireless) sent to Australia. News from Sydney & Melbourne. Sporting results and a threatening strike.

July 8th

A ships'concert on "D Deck".

A message of welcome to the "Rio-Pardo" and her troops, is received by W.A. Holman.

Some of the boys also receive personal messages from Australia.

July 9th

The sports are continued - Tug o' war competitions - A ship of 3,200.

Further study of "Principles and Practice of Elocution".

Perfect weather becomes our lot as we draw nearer to our native-land. Our position on the map is conducive to much good humour amongst the troops.

Evening hymn service proves highly popular.

Many are the conjectures now made daily as to

when we will make Melbourne. Friday July 18th is the favourite day.

July 10th

Continuation of the second stage of "ship's sports". Success of Sergeants in the tug-o'war. Is it due to superior food?

Can sea-pie possibly cope with eggs & bacon?

During the day many eyes are rivetted on the ships chart, for the indicator is now travelling from West to East at an interesting rate.

An hour in the "Literary Class". An interesting paper on Charles Dicken's by Pte Fowler, after which we discuss authors and their work.

By common consent I represent our deck on the committee which is to consider a token of appreciation and esteem to be given to the Padre.

July 11th

Wireless news from Australia.

The Seamens Strike in Melbourne threatens to develop into a Nation-

Debate" (Should drink be nationalised?)

al disorganisation of industries. During the afternoon I have no difficulty in winning the ship's skipping contest (348 in 2 minutes). In the evening the Padre
the
 gives a very interesting lecture on his travels in 1911 to London and then to France. Germany. Switzerland. Italy. Greece. Palestine. Egypt. etc.

July 12h

Further news makes the outlook in Australia anything but hopeful. As a consequence the "Rio

Pardo" will now disembark all S. Australian & Victorian troops at Adelaide and will then proceed to Hobart. From there we will make for Sydney.

An essay on "Affection" written for tomorrow's class.

Our boys are daily growing more high-spirited, and good feeling rules each day.

July 13

Sunday -

Church Service



An excellent sermon!

Death of the ship's mascot - The monkey dies after eating an indelible pencil.

£40 collected between the decks for the Padre's presentation - and a wireless is sent to Adelaide to order the article.

Afternoon Bible Class & Evening Hymn Service during which I recite for the first time "Jim Baxter'.

Continuation of "Elm Bank" letter.

A paper on "
Affection
" given at "afternoon class".

July 14th

Second meeting of our "Literary Class" at which Private Loam gives an interest digest on a book entitled " Can we set the World in Motion? (Enock).

"A & B Decks" defeat "C & D" in a Debate the subject of which is Should Bachelors be Taxed?

Preparation of a paper on "The Newspaper".

July 15th

We are now crossing the "Bight"

and the seas are considerably rougher than what they have been for the past week.

- The whole of the day is spent in preparing my paper for the Literary Class.

Officers & Sergeants defeated by the Privates in a debate:- "Is the League of Nations Practicable?

July 16th

A days sail from Adelaide!

Victorians & South Australians spend the

day in polishing boots, button, badges etc. Letters written to Home.

In the evening a Concert and Prize-giving takes place.

"A Fantasy" (one of my War poems) gives delight to the "boys" and satisfaction to myself.

July 17th

On rising we see Australia, under an Australian blue sky. It is three and a half years since I last sailed through this Gulf and four years since I donned

khaki. It seems like a lifetime! - it seems but yesterday! All men who are to disembark this day are wildly excited and we can but look on with envy, and of course a great amount of joy. After we are cleared by Customs & Health Officers we put into the Outer Harbour of Adelaide. A letter from Mrs Bice is brought to me, but unfortunately I am unable to comply with what it contains.

A cheer goes up as

the "Rio Pardo" hits Australia. The Sth Australians & Victorians land and others of us 
goe
 go ashore to stretch our legs. Roy, as usual, provides "home comforts" and after supper we turn in and sleep nearer to Home than we have been for a long, long time.

July 18th

Letters & telegrams have been sent from Adelaide - and so the news will be there today.

At 7 a.m. we are piloted

out of the Harbour and set sail for Tasmania (we know not which Port).

A great day with plenty of warm, bright sunshine. If this Winter, it is going to be dreadfully hot in Summer.

I am now in charge of the Isolation Hospital, but luckily there are no patients.

July 19th

With strong wind behind us we put up our greatest mileage - 275 for the day. Two patients

come under our care. Luckily they are bound for the "Spec" - and so up-to-date our chances of being quarantined are "nil".

July 20th

Another good days sailing takes us further away, but brings us nearer Home.

In the afternoon I give a paper which constitutes a Literary digest of a book entitled "The Newspaper".

Our Literary Class is considerably depleted but

a good number assemble on the sergeants' deck.

In the evening a "digger" who was a prisoner of war in Germany for two years gives 
a
 a very interesting account of his imprisonment.

The work of the "Red Cross" and German cruelty are the outstanding features of his experience.

A short concert programme is given in addition.

July 21st

At an early hour we enter the Port of

Hobart and anchor in Barnes Bay. From
e
 there all Tasmanians are taken to the "quarantine station" in a very small launch. The water is rather rough and great amusement is afforded us by the attempts of the "Tassies" to get from one boat to the other. Unfortunately (for them) it will be necessary to do 7 days in quarantine.

One of the ship's boats gets adrift and causes more merriment

After all the "Tassies" have left the Rio Pardo, quite reluctantly, I am sure! - we steam out to sea once again.

Of course the anchor is lifted before doing so.

A very rough sea proves friendly after we turn North.

July 22nd

A bright, sunny day! At noon we have 411 miles to travel to "Our Harbour".

We now number 150 N.S.Welshmen and 40 Queenslanders.

"World Builders All" is read for the third time. The "diggers" start cleaning up.

Kiwi is discovered in the bottom of old kitbags.

A yarn with the Padre. Final Active Service Pay called in the evening.

July 23rd

The first sight of "Sunny New South Wales". On a glorious morning we cruise within two miles of the South Coast,

and throughout the day we sail quite close to the blue-enveloped shores of the "Mother State".

It is just eight weeks since we set out from Devonport. What promised to be a slow & monotonous voyage, has certainly been slow but (thanks to the Padre) far from monotonous.

It is now over, save for the all-important arrival, and we are all grateful for the protection, guidance & salvation which He has given us.

During the day, "discharge & furlough" papers are filled in - and general preparations made for the morrow.

We expect to disembark at 10.30 a.m.

The sea is wonderfully calm, and strange to say, so are the troops.

July 24th

The evenful day is very eventful, if not altogether pleasing. At day break we sight the "dear old Heads" and while our hearts

are leaping with joy we behold the "Captain Cook" (pilot ship) coming out of the harbour to meet and escort us.

As it draws alongside the Commander, through a trumpet is heard to say - "The Rio Pardo will sail around to North Head for purpose of quarantine." The whole ship then waxed wrath and for a short time I must confess the air was "blue".

After casting anchor, the very pleasing

news is told us that we one of the men who left our vessel at Hobart had been taken ill and we were all suspected contacts of small pox.

But a word about our beautiful Harbour. It is a veritable paradise; a gift of Nature of which we may well be proud. It is the only Harbour I have seen for 3½ years.

We could appreciate it more, and rhapsodise at greater length, only for the thoughts of North Head!

But then are we not privileged in being allowed there? It is not everybody that can go to North Head - and I am sure it is not everybody that is anxious to remain there after a few hours have passed. On going ashore we have hot baths and all clothes and belonging are cleansed and fumigated.

Then we graciously retire to our huts.

Before leaving the Pardo I am

most fortunate in seeing for the first time my loved ones - who have come from Home in a motor launch.

July 25th to July 28th

After spending five days in the quarantine station our vaccination marks are examined and we are then classified.

The food during these days is very poor and the life is frightfully slow. Our great consolations

are in the forms of newspapers and a public telephone, around which the men swarm about fifty strong and await their turn.

On Sunday evening we have our final Service and the Padre gives good advice.

On Monday morning, much to our great relief a number of our party leave the "Station" for our Homes.

We travel to Woolloo-

molloo in a ferry-boat and find it particularly rough crossing the "Heads" . From Woolloomolloo we are carried to the Anzac Buffet in motor cars, and after a great deal of trouble owing to wretched weather and congestion we become finalised and then after joyful meetings we go

Diary -

April 5th 1919 to

April 5th

Arrive Southampton 1 a.m. - Night passed on deck owing to the overcrowding of sleeping apartments down below.

Anchored in Southampton Harbour till 6 a.m. when we steam into the wharf and there immediately disembark. A free breakfast and a train ration. Entrain and leave Southampton at 10 a.m.

The pleasant land of England in Spring -

Bursting through the dead brown leaves which cover the woody country, little green leaves & creepers are to be seen. The bare branches of the trees show signs of returning life, and the early Spring flowers 
and
 are budding and nodding in the sun-lit fields -"Oh to be in England now that April's here!"

Pass through Salisbury Wilton etc and disentrain at Warminster

March to No. 6 Camp Sutton Veny. This district and surrounding country have many Australian Camps for War-time training purposes & for convalescents - Medical Inspection. Allotted to Huts - Liberal issue of blankets - food etc.

April 6th

Sabbath

Inoculated once again.

Letter writing.

Visit Y.M.C.A. & other Huts - Marked

superiority of these institutions in England over those in France. A walk to Warminster on a particularly fine day.

April 7th

Morning & Afternoon parades. Routine orders etc. More letters written. Again Meet Bob Roberts. Ern Payne. Ben Davies etc. Mr. John Goddard Entertainer.

April 8th

Parade. Diary. A break in the weather.

Raining throughout the day.

April 9th

Visit 1st Aust. General Hospital with Ben Davies. Afternoon tea with the Sisters.

Musical items etc. "Greenhill" & "Manor House".

April 10th

Again meet Keith Harris.

Preparations for furlough. For first time we have to pay for Railway Tickets. "An injustice or not"- Army masqueraders - and a "camp robbery". Meet Mrs Wighram of Manor House and give a few items. The village of Sutton and the Cemetery.

April 11th

Reveille at 5 a.m. Leave camp at 7 a.m. for Warminster

Station where we entrain. - How different from proceeding on leave in France! On the journey we pass the factories of "Huntley & Palmer" - and "TIcklers" - Scotts Emulsion - Victor Tyres - "His Master's Voice" etc.

- The White Horse and the Rising Sun on the Hillside.

Arrive Paddington 11 a.m. "Elm Bank" mid-day.

Afternoon with the pen. Evening with Mr & Mrs Scales & friends - The Misses Sargent.

- A late return to Hornsey Lane.

April 12th

Late breakfast.- A run into town.

Personal purchases.

Book at Theatres.

Spend afternoon at Mme Tussaud's famous Wax Works and evening at the "Court Theatre" where we

see "The School for Scandal (Sheridan) by the "Twelfth Night" cast. A great play with Herbert Waring the outstanding feature.

April 13th

Sabbath

Letter-writing - Diary.

Meet Bert Chesters. A long talk about old times & coming events. Afternoon & evening spent with Mr & Mrs Harold Scales - Elm Bank.

April 14th

Parcels made up & posted. More letters written. Poems copied. A busy day. Spend evening at Wimbledon where the great Tennis Courts are - Wimbledon Common.

April 15th

Morning in town. Book buying. Parcel posting. Visit the Canadian Beaver Hut.

Go to Hammersmith (A.I.F. Kit stores) but am not successful in obtaining old kit bag. Return to Elm Bank. Discuss future plans. A quiet, happy conversation.

Garrick Theatre in the Evening - "Cyranode Bergerac" by the French Dramatist Edmond Rostand and featuring Robert Lorraine late B.E.F. in the name part

An excellent play with a weak cast and some faulty production. Stage too small for spectacular effects - Amateur acting - a great last act.

April 16th

Parcels - Letters - Diary - Kings Cross - Drury Lane - "Samson & Delilah". An Australian in the audience. A hurried departure, and a night in the corridor

(Edna Thornton, Frederick Blaney)

of the Scotch express.

April 17th

Arrive Waverley Station at 8 a.m. Again meet all at "59" - where I am made a guest. A morning in bed - an afternoon in "Auld Reekie" and an evening of music

April 18th

Meet "Bert" the American brother and David. A visit to the Leith Docks where we see the

interned German Vessels. A "picture house" - D. Fairbanks.

Last hours at "59" . Take train at Waverlry for London 10 p.m.

Farewell to my Scotch friends.

April 19th

After a nights travelling I arrive at Kings Cross at 7.30 a.m.

Go to Waterloo for purpose of enquiry.

Return to "Elm Bank" - Australian & other

mail. Leave Waterloo 12.30 - after a pleasant journey and a change at Brochenhurst. I arrive at "Mentone" Milford-on-Sea at 3.30 a.m. Milford overlooks the Sea and in the hazy distance lies the Isle of Wight.

A jolly walk along the cliffs with Mr Scales, Mrs Matthews, Honor and Joyce. Much talk and laughter.

A game of whist!

April 20th

"Sabbath" - Church Service - an hour on the beach - Ducks and drakes on the water. Rhymes of a "Red Cross Man".

Letters written. Diary.

Beautiful Milford - spring weather.

Evening service at the Milford Church. Several Recitations.

April 21st

An early morning walk along the sea-cliffs.

The fascination of the Ocean. Read & conclude book of "Prayer".

A very enjoyable & interesting motor excursion. Starting from Mentone we pass along the Sway Road through Lymington & Lyndhurst. At Lyndhurst (20 miles from Bournemouth) we enter the local church famous for the fresco behind the Altar painted by Lord Leighton.

A beautiful modern Church. An organ recital.

Resuming our journey we pass several old inns including "The Wheel Inn" & "Ye Olde Servants Inn" - and arrive at the New Forest famous for
 En 
early English Hunting - Roman Roads. In the "forest
s
" we see the "Rufus' Stone" on whose three sides are inscribed:

(1) "Here stood the oak-tree on which an arrow shot by Sir Walter Tyrell at a stag, glanced and struck King William II (Rufus)

in the breast of which he instantly died on the 2nd day of August anno 1100. King William II being slain, as is before related, was laid in a cart belonging to one Purkess and drawn from thence to Winchester and buried in the Cathedral Church of that city.

(II) That where an event so memorable had happened might not hereafter be unknown, this stone was set up by Lord Delaware, who had seen the tree growing in

this place anno 1745. This stone was repaired by John Richard, Earl of Delaware anno 1789.

(III) This stone having been much mutilated, and the inscriptions on each of its three sides defaced, this more durable memorial, with the original inscriptions, was erected in the year 1841 by William Sturges Bourne, warden.

The New Forest and its resemblance to parts of Blue Mountains

Return to the car and commence the return journey. After a run of a mile we stop at Minstead and enter the most quaint little church I have yet seen. The structure is of the 13th century, being restored 100 years ago. Private family pews - A double gallery - and the "old three part pulpit" provide an interesting inspection. The run back to Milford-on-Sea

along the Sway Rd and on towards the Mount past The Wheel Inn & Wain's Ford Bridge past Col. Cornwallis-West's House - A great trip! After dinner we take a walk along the cliffs and then indulge in a game of cards. Much amusement & hilarity - Bed.

April 22nd

Ealy morning walk on the

seashore. Mrs Matthews, Mrs Scales, Honor, Joyce and self leave for Isle of Wight.

Mr Scales returns to London & Mr Matthews cycles to Southampton.

Our party take the motor bus from Milford to Lymington Station then walk to Lymington Pier. From there we board a steamer and sail across to Yarmouth in the Isle of Wight.

Honor Joyce & myself then set out on our walking excursion. Passing along beautiful country roads and lanes whose hedges trees, vines & creepers are smiling with the advent of Spring we soon make the cliffs of Alum Bay overlooking "The Needless". The blue waters of the Solent on such a bright sunny days present a fascin-

ating aspect.. Leaving Alum Bay we stroll to Freshwater Bay & rejoin Mrs Scales & Mrs Matthews on the beach. After a repast we return to Yarmouth in a brake and there take the ferry back to Lymington and a conveyance to Mentone - a day which will be forever remembered.

Honor & Joyce - two English girls

whose unaffected good-nature and whose high spirits make them such jolly companions and good friends. Diary. Cards.

April 23rd

A morning walk along the cliffs.

Shopping in the village with Mrs Scales.

An hour on the beach. A very precious hour indeed, during which I have my last long

talk to my "dearest friend" - Soul communion in the presence of Christ.

Afternoon of letter-writing and reading on the cliffs.

Poems read to my friends - Evening, while the twilight lasts is spent in the "Pine Wood" - Barry Pain causes laughter.

Last game of cards. Much hilarity!

Bed.

April 24th

Early breakfast.

Make preparations and set out for the village. My brave "English Mother" - Our sad & painful farewell.

Bid "good bye" to Mr & Mrs Matthews, Honor & Joyce whose great kindness is beyond my poor expression.

Motor bus to Lymington - Train to Paddington (changing at Brockenhurst)

Shopping in town.

Return to Elm-Bank.

Evening spent in making up parcels, writing letters etc.

April 25th

"Anzac Day" - Anniversary of the Glorious Gallipoli Landing - Australians march in the City. Decorations, speeches etc. Shopping. Final business.

Farewell to Mr & Mrs Harold Scales & the children.

Diary - letters & preparation for to-morrow's departure.

April 26th

Most reluctantly and with a sad heart I leave "Elm Bank" - and later in town I bid farewell to Mr Scales.

Take 10.15 a.m. train from Paddington to Warminster. Return to Sutton Veny Camp.

Report to Orderly Room & take up new quarters. Blanket

& ration issue. The end of a perfect furlough.

Early to bed.

April 27th 
(Sabbath)

The Anniversary (51st) of Mrs Scales' Birthday. A mail received and many letters written.

A walk around the camps. The lonely feeling - Past memories & future prospects. The New Testament & its friendship.

April 28th

Stormy weather.

Despite "time & season" we have a heavy fall of snow.

Commence reading "Wuthering Heights".

More letters received & written. Receive pay-book. Evening stroll.

April 29th

Much appreciated letters from Mr & Mrs Scales. Obtain my old sea kit bag which I have not seen for over three years.

The atomizer in good order.

Majority of possessions missing. Morning parade. Warned for an early move to Fovant. Conclude "Wuthering Heights" and read a short book on Christianity & the War.

Letters. Diary.

April 30th

Anzac Sports day in the grounds of "Greenhill'. Letters received & written. Commence copying

1917 Diary. Many are the rumours concerning early embarkations etc.

Greenhill Y.M.C.A.



- 1919 -

- May -

May 1st

"May-day"

Read & copy excerpts of "God's Right of Way". My growing interest in books of Christian knowledge. Unsettled weather. Keith Harris - now a father.

May 2nd

A cold hot shower - Copy 1917 Diary - Afternoon fatigue duty. The unloading & stacking of 20,000 blankets.

The first chapters of a new book "The Christian Message" - Happy days. The value of earnest prayer.

May 3rd

At 1 a.m. the greater part of our 23rd Quota leave camp for London to take part in the "Dominions March".

Complete reading of "The Christian Message".

Books bought & boxed from the Education

al Library. Letters from London & Belgium.

The daily refreshments.

May 4th

Letters to Home & "Elm Bank". Read "Fight for the Future" (E.A. Burroughs). Yesterdays injustices to Australians in the march and the result. Ration duties. An afternoon walk along a country road in the direction of Heylesbury - and

a bright "Evening Service" in "Greenhills".

May 5th

Fatigue duties.

Conclude "Fight for the Future". Resume transcription of 1917 Diary.

Commence study of "An Introduction to Study of English Literature" (Hudson).

Movement orders. Preparation for departure.

May 6th

Early reveille.

Move out of Sutton Veny

to Warminster. Entrain for Fovant. Pass through records office. Camp greatly over crowded. Many "old faces'. Old tales re-told.

May 7th

Morning parade. Tent erecting duties. Letter writing. A walk to the village of Fovant - Tipperary Hut - New & old friends.

May 8th

Fatigue duties.

Diary & Letters.

Camp Life monotony. Evening at the Garrison Cinema.

May 9th

The art of missing parades. A long walk, through Hurdcott and to the little English village of "Barford St. Martin". Letter writing & 1917 Diary.

May 10th

Boat roll for the "Nestor" (previous trip H.R.A.). 54 men

chosen. Not amongst the fortunate. Bag re-packed. Letters written .

A woodland walk - Spring and its effect.

May 11th

Letters written. More walks. Still waiting & watching. Some men I know in camp:- Sgts. Spain-Davey. Steele. Hand. Troup. Godfrey. Nugent. Eric Mills & Pres O'Brien. Murray. Roy McLaren. Hugo Robinson. Lenehan. Wasson. Doig

Harden. Campbell. Zarka. McMillan. Hatchet. Ritson. etc. etc. "Durham" & "Themistocles" to leave very shortly.

Jack Davey departs for Port Napier.

May 12th

Morning parade - white washing duties!! More men march into Fovant. Correspondence.

May 13th

My woodland haunt! In the midst of primroses and a violet coloured flower with the perfume of wisteria

I read & write. A beautiful spot in a beautiful island breaks the camp life monotony.

May 14th

Morning showers & evening walks. A new poem entitled "Spring" - Preparation & study of additional items. Letters.

May 15th

Another boat roll - the "Durham" to sail via the Panama.

"The Crucifix" "Edith Cavell" & the "White Cross" written.

Australia plays cricket.
Entry.96:
Mail from Home (March 31st). An erroneous address! Influx of A.M.C. men.

More old friends arrive.
Entry.97:
Greater ease in verse writing. The value of practice in rhythm and rhyming. War poems. Letter & some delicious chocolates from "Westcott".

The Benjamin.
Entry.98:
The Peace Terms &

the German resentment. Marshall Toch goes to the Rhine. Parades & duties. Sunny days & fair flowers!
Entry.99:
Our Australian airman Hawker leaves America for the Trans-Atalantic flight.

At last I am placed on a boat-roll. Our vessel the "Rio Padro" is to leave Devonport on the 27th inst.

Meet George Chapman

Fifth Division Quotas arrive from Weymouth.

Alexander Watson in camp.

More verses and also letters written.
Entry.100: "Rio Padro" - a vessel of 8,000 tons, which will carry 750 men. Farewell letters. Glorious weather. Washing day.
Entry.101:
No news of Harry Hawker. The worst is feared. Australia predominates in Sport.

More farewell letters.

News from Harold.

Twenty poems written in 9 days. Archie Martin & other friends now in camp.
Entry.102:
Pay-day.

Ralph returns with surprising news. Complete letters. "The Australian Rag".

World-wide sympathy for the lost heroic airmen.

The Diggers feel it very much.

Courage of aviators wife!

S. S. "Rio Pardo"
Entry.103:
Final preparations - at 3.30 p.m. the A.M.C. quotas for the "Bremen" & "Rio Pardo" march out of Fovant Camp. Train to Salisbury then to Waterloo.

Night at War Chest Club.
Entry.104:
(Empire Day)

Our quota for "Rio Pardo" leave town for the Surrey Docks.

"Good bye big smokey London with its millions of people and its very happy memories!

First impressions of our transport. They are

not over agreeable!

Afternoon and evening in Bermondsey - A dirty district - Back to hammock-life.

Meet a very old pal. Roy Cooney from North Sydney & S.H.S.

I am delighted to have his companionship.
Entry.105:
(Sunday) - Draw out from Surrey Docks & down the Thames.

Mess Orderly duties. Good meals, and a clean vessel
s
.

Great news!- Harry Hawker & Commander Grieve saved. Letter written to my "English Lady". We are allotted to life-boats. Old days recalled with Roy.
Entry.106:
Mond
 Cruising from the Thames to Devonport. A run along the South Coast of England in fine weather.

Carrying duties.

In the evening we make Plymouth and

anchor in the stream.
Entry.107:
Plymouth Harbour. Natural beauty. Not unlike Farm Cove in parts. The Rio Padro passes up stream and is moored to a wharf in the naval docks
yard
. The troops for the Pardo arrive per train. They consist
s
 chiefly of 3rd Div. Infantry.

Band selections by 39th Battalion. A last letter!
Entry.108:
Reveille 6.30.

Account of Hawker''s & Grieve's rescue & return.

Australians to the front!

Stirring scenes.

At 11 a.m. we draw out from the wharf at Devonport and sail slowly down the harbour of Plymouth. While our band plays patriotic airs - "Auld Lang Syne" . "Good-byee" and lumps rise in our throats (for after all we are human & have human sympathies).

The Commanders, officers and crews of Britains Iron-clads stand-to and give us rousing cheers. By submarine destroyer. cruiser & battleship bearing the "Jack" and in some cases the "Stars & Stripes" we are truly honoured in a British manner and given a farewell so sincere & spirited that the passing years cannot possibly efface its stirring memories.

With a stilled tongue

and a heavy heart I watch dear old England fade from view. There is but little more to be said. I am thinking deeply and my thoughts are fashioned into prayers.

God bless all & everything in the greatest island in the universe! Australia is a continent.

The letter is read; the sun sinks in the west - our ship draws nearer Home. Night covers it in the

broad expanse of sea.

May God watch over and protect us now and at all times!
Entry.109:
In the Atlantic - The Rio Pardo rather exceeds our expectations in regard
s
 to speed & sea worthiness.

We have a mascot on board - "Ginny" the monkey.

Y.M.C.A. & Canteen opens. A game of crib. Night in a hammock.
Entry.110:
The introduction off a chart marking our daily course and rate of travelling proves very popular. At mid-day we are 510 miles from Devonport after having passed the Bay of Biscay.

Read "The Regent" (Arnold Bennett).

Keeping fit! How it is accomplished on a transport.
Entry.111:
Last day of

the month. At noon we are lying due west from Cape St. Vincent.

Punching balls, gloves & medicine balls introduced. The weather hotter & finer and the sea a good deal calmer.

Favourable winds prove most welcome.

During the day I read & much enjoy"Echoes of the War" (J.M. Barrie).

Recite at a "Sing Song" on "A" Deck.

1919

June -
Entry.112:
Sunday. Church Service on the "Rio Pardo". Our Padre a very popular man.

The boat shows a daily increase in speed. We are now approaching the Canary Islands. The first instalment of my long "English" letter is written and it will be continued on subsequent Sundays.

During the evening

I obtain & commence reading the Holy Bible - also a small book entitled "How to Master the Bible (Gray).

A Sunday night "hymn service" is a fitting & happy conclusion to the Sabbath.
Entry.113:
Morning parade & physical exercise.

The "Rio Pardo" stops in mid-ocean and drifts for two hours. Roy, Alf & self resort to dominoes & "rummy"

Windsor Castle (Ainsworth) from Y.M.C.A. Library provides interesting reading. A concert on the aft-well deck." "Suri Bair" & "Polyglot".

Nightly study of the Bible. In the tropics. The sun is now getting well overhead and is intensely warm.
Entry.114:
Morning parade & inspection. Two small canvas swimming baths are erected near

the forecastle (pardon - foc 'sle!) - and afford much comfort and delight to the diggers.

Afternoon deck sports.

Evening card tournaments.
Entry.115:
Complete the reading of "Windsor Castle . Evening song & hymn service.

Commence the study of English Grammar.

The deck baths provide much fun. The book of Genesis - Story of "Abide with me".
Entry.116:
Tropical weather does not appeal to the men after leaving the pleasant clime of England. A growing friendship gives much enjoyment and relieves the days of monotony.

Dolphins & porpoises racing with the boat and leaping from the water and flying fishes skimming above the waves provide a little diversion.

Morning parades & inspection
Entry.117:
Before noon our "transport" passes beetween Cape Verde & C. Verde Islands. Unfortunately we see neither - nor have we seen land since leaving England. The study of "English Grammar".

In the evening we are very happy to behold the "Southern Cross"in the sky.

Before turning in I havea little relaxation in the deck swimming tank.
Entry.118:
Trouble brewing! The fireman are apparently shorthanded and are being over-worked. In the forenoon we pass Sierra Leone.

The weather grows more oppressive daily - and we are not yet to the "Line".

Commence "Society & Solitude" (Emerson).

Acquatic sports. More dolphins and a shark.
Entry.119:
Sunday -

While on deck reading an essay on "Eloquence" by Emerson, a great change takes place. From afar, a storm can be seen sweeping up from the South, and shortly after we are passing through torrents of rain and the oppressive air grows cooler, as the seas grow more tempestuous.

How wildly, madly eloquent is a storm

at sea and how attentive we become to the voices of the elements. The deep vibrato of the thunder and the shrill piping of the overhead winds are strangely contrasted yet it is one & the same voice with its great range and its wild threatening speech.

As the day draws into 
int
 night the storm clears and we have a bright service on deck.

Also some "lantern slides"

and a "request poem".

Second instalment of my letter to "Elm Bank".
Entry.120:
"Society Solitude" (Emerson) - "Outline of English Grammar".

The Boxing tournaments commence. Short-lived bouts. Band recital. Draughts. cards & discussions.

I make a new friend - Corporal Dubois and memories of Ballarat in 1913.

June 10th

Deck parades and ship's inspection.

First comes the ship's Commander dressed in white, closely followed by the O.C. of the troops.

Then a retinue walking in the rear and halting. smiling & frowning when the "Captain & Colonel" halt, smile & frown. They proceed in this order:- Ship's mates 1st &
Entry.121:
- Troop's & ship's doctors. orderly officer. orderly sergeant. ship's

O.M.S., Orderly Corporal and a few "spare parts" - numbering in all 12 men drawing 
about
 more than £15 a day for their great responsibillities or £900 for the trip.

Who pays?

Second day of boxing. Short fights with tragic endings.

A Bible class under the Padre.
Entry.122:
Finals of the Boxing - A small

man beats a big man and gains much applause.

Corporal Brown hits out and Private Giles lays out.

Our deck "B" gives a popular concert. In addition to reciting I make my initial effort to 
a
 jazz accompanied ragtime.

"Solitude & Society". An interesting & absorbing book by Emerson.
Entry.123:
Deck quoit.

competitions. Complete reading of "Society & Solitude".

English Grammar proves hard reading & study.

The Southern Cross still beckons us on to a Southern land and a Southern sun.

Our ship turns and apparently goes N.W. for a few miles then turns again to her old course.
Entry.124:
Morning study. Preparation of lessons

for afternoon.

A long talk with our Padre. Read "Poems of Optimism" and "Kingdom of Love" (E.W. Wilcox). The troop-ship "Aneas" which left Devonport three days after the "Rio Pardo" is now only a short distance behind us. Daily our vessel registers shorter distances.

As we draw away from the Equator the weather becomes

colder and the sea rougher.
Entry.125:
A day spent chiefly with book and pen. A chapter by Donald Haukey.

A new book "Quiet talks about the Tempter" (Gordon). Owing to certain throat troubles all the troops undergo a throat spraying operation.

"B" Decks adds points to their aggregate.

in point score competition.
Entry.126:
Sabbath.

Morning Church Service. Afternoon Bible Study. Third part of the "Elm Bank" letter is written.

Our vessel is now only 1,400 miles from Cape Town. Is the Southern Cross shining more brightly as we draw nearer Home - or does that fact make it appear so!

To-morrow is the 16th.



June
. Cook holding 30 francs

" We owe H.R, 20 francs.
